org.usfirst.frc2084.CMonster2014.drive

Class WheelController

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.usfirst.frc2084.CMonster2014.drive.WheelController

  • public class WheelController
extends java.lang.Object
    Controls a single wheel with an arbitrary number of motors. In many cases this will actually control a single wheel, but in designs where two wheels are connected to the same gearbox (such as most tank drive systems), it will actually control two wheels.
    Author:
    Ben Wolsieffer

        Parameters:
        motor - the SpeedController that powers the wheel
        motor2 - the second SpeedController that powers the wheel
        motor3 - the third SpeedController that powers the wheel

      • WheelController

        public WheelController(edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.SpeedController[] motors)
        Creates a new WheelController with an arbitrary number of motors. This constructor is only necessary if one wheel has more than 3 motors (which seems unlikely), otherwise use the 1, 2, or 3 parameter versions of the constructor.
        Parameters:
        motors - the array of SpeedController that powers the wheel

    • Method Detail

      • set

        public void set(double speed)
        Sets the speed of the wheel. For a basic wheel this just sets the power to the motor but this class can be extended for more complex functionality.
        Parameters:
        speed - the wheel speed between 1.0 and -1.0

      • setInverted

        public void setInverted(boolean inverted)
        Sets whether this wheel should be inverted.
        Parameters:
        inverted - whether the wheel is inverted

      • isInverted

        public boolean isInverted()
        Gets whether or not the wheel is inverted.
        Returns:
        the inverted state
